Cold involves fully redundant, immediately available systems; Warm includes partially redundant systems activated in hours; Hot entails backup data stored offline.
Hot involves fully redundant, immediately available systems; Cold includes no redundant systems, relying on backup restoration; Warm is in-between with partially redundant systems.
Warm involves systems running at reduced efficiency to save costs; Cold entails offline data storage, accessed as needed; Hot is typically used for non-essential applications.
Cold strategies require manual intervention for all processes; Hot is used exclusively for data archiving; Warm leverages cloud services for instantaneous recovery.

EC2 is a platform for deploying applications while Elastic Beanstalk is a compute service for running applications.

Elastic Beanstalk provides a managed environment to deploy applications, handling the infrastructure with more abstraction, whereas EC2 provides scalable computing capacity with more control over the environment.
Elastic Beanstalk is primarily used for database services, whereas EC2 is used for deploying and managing containerized applications.
EC2 is focused on networking services, while Elastic Beanstalk is an email sending service.
